Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Production and Assessment of Student-Authored Wiki Textbooks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer Science (31)

Emerging information technologies are enabling new forms of content delivery. Students are provided with the opportunity of writing a peer-reviewed textbook for their own course. Instead of being merely the consumers of knowledge, students become co-producers, along with the instructor. This is forcing them to learn the material in greater depth, and to reflect upon it more frequently. The natural medium for the creation of such a textbook is a wiki, because it standardizes the format and makes it easy for students to edit parts of a larger work. This project is combining two sets of expertise: wiki textbook creation and software for peer review of student-generated content.

A software system to manage the creation and peer review of a wiki textbook has several automating features. These features include rubric creation by students, double-blind feedback between author and reviewer, and quality-control strategies for student peer reviews. This software system also provides support for flow management to allow different chapters of the text to be written and reviewed at different times during the course of the creation to support this experience.

This project is advancing understanding in a variety of disciplines by engaging students in knowledge generation as well as knowledge acquisition. Students not only learn existing material better, but they uncover and codify new knowledge for their peers. This gives students first-hand experience with the process of inquiry and scientific discovery.

By making it easier to manage the writing of a wiki textbook in a class, it encourages instructors to have their students write wiki textbooks. Finally, the software system that is being developed is adoptable in disciplines other than STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaborative effort by a professor of computer science from North Carolina State University and a teacher educator from Old Dominion University. They joined forces to refine strategies and tools that facilitate the creation of student-authored digital textbooks.  By collaboratively creating their own course textbook each semester, the pre-service teachers at Old Dominion University learned to present and evaluate content, and to give and receive feedback, critical skills for future teachers. Each student created a lesson for the textbook and evaluated lessons designed by peers.  As part of the development process, students engaged in peer review and provided formative feedback on lesson drafts. Authors responded to reviewers helping them understand the effectiveness of their feedback. This project helped the education students develop the 21st century skills they will need in their future classrooms.

As with any complex project, structural support is essential. With large courses delivered both face-to-face and online, the logistics required to manage this project become increasingly challenging. Herein was the primary need for the project. Software developed at NC State, called Expertiza, was used to manage the textbook production process. It orchestrated the formation of teams and the peer review process.  In order to meet the needs of larger class sizes and to accommodate in-depth and multi-modal feedback, the PI’s team at NC State had to design new features in Expertiza and refine existing ones. Instructors can now create complex rubrics supporting qualitative and quantitative items including checklists, rating scales, fill-in-the-blank, and extended response entries. Instructors can also permit students to select the topics of the lessons they review or be randomly assigned to them. Expertiza now ensures that entries are reviewed systematically so each lesson receives the same number of reviews.

In addition to evaluating and refining the Expertiza software system, the project also tested and evaluated other tools to support the creation of student-authored digital textbooks. A custom media-wiki based application was designed and used at Old Dominion University, but ultimately abandoned because it could not be maintained without sustained funding. As such it became important to evaluate existing and freely available tools. Google Sites was tested as a platform to host a student-authored text with Google forms used to support evaluation.  It was determined that the free version of Google Sites did not provide adequate memory capacity to support a student-authored text developed collaboratively by a class of students, but space allotted with the educational apps version of Google Sites was sufficient. Google forms was found to be an effective means to create rubrics for peer review and peer assessment, but did not provide a logistical solution for managing the peer review process with a large number of students. Expertiza was found to be superior for supporting logistic processes. In short, creating and assessing a student-authored textbooks with Google Sites and Google forms was determined to be a viable option for a small class of students. Another free tool, Jing, was evaluated for its potential to provide multimedia feedback during peer reviews. This was found effective and can be integrated into either Google forms, Expertiza or other document-based review system.

In total, eleven student-authored wiki textbooks were created by Old Dominion University undergraduate students. Students reported primarily positive experiences using the wiki textbook creation and review tools and indicated that they learned from creating and reviewing the text and that they read the completed text critically.
